content: <response><row><row _id="2" _uuid="33B50ADF-C9DE-4B48-A4BD-B1C1D789FD08" _position="2" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/2"><creator>Robert Lee Eskridge</creator><credit>Funded by the Works Progress Administration</credit><date>1935</date><description>One of a pair of murals at the Lester McCoy Pavilion at Ala Mona Regional Park. A Works Progress Administration art project, done in the Art Deco style. It depicts various aspects of makahiki (harvest festival), imagined as taking place in the vicinity of what is now know as Ala Mona Park, makahiki pa'ani ho'oikaika (annual sports tournaments) are emphasized. This mural shows ali'i (chiefs) guided by the spirit of Lono (one of the four major Hawaiian gods, associated with peace and fertility) being presented with ho'okupu (tribute). In the distance kahuna (priests) guard the kapa (bark cloth) double banner of Lono. In the background are the silhouette of Lae'ahi (Diamond Head) and the village of Waikiki (spouting water). Sports represented are he'e holua (sled racing), mokomoko (hand-to-hand fighting), and 'ulu maika (bowling), dance and music are represented with 'uli'uli (gourd rattle), pahu (drum), and mahiole (helmet).</description><location>Lester McCoy Pavilion</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/19300101.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1930.01.01</objectid><discipline>Mural</discipline><title>The Makahiki Festival - The Makai Mural</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.290824</latitude><longitude>-157.85131</longitude><artloc latitude="21.290824" longitude="-157.85131" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="3" _uuid="ABB57E11-6D8A-42DB-9251-EC374F1FD302" _position="3" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/3"><creator>Sean Browne</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><date>2001</date><description>Bronze figure of Prince Jonah Kuhio Kalanianaole. Located at Kuhio Beach.</description><location>Kuhio Beach</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/003/002_200105.JPG</imagefile><objectid>2001.05</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Prince Jonah Kuhio Kalanianaole</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.273389</latitude><longitude>-157.823802</longitude><artloc latitude="21.273389" longitude="-157.823802" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="4" _uuid="4DB83484-E43D-4BAF-9CC7-F3E8E014FAF3" _position="4" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/4"><creator>Robert Lee Eskridge</creator><credit>Funded by the Works Progress Administration</credit><date>1935</date><description>One of a pair of murals at the Lester McCoy Pavilion at Ala Mona Regional Park. A Works Progress Administration art project, done in the Art Deco style. It depicts various aspects of makahiki (harvest festival), imagined as taking place in the vicinity of what is now know as Ala Mona Park, makahiki pa'ani ho'oikaika (annual sports tournaments) are emphasized. This mural depicts ali'i with their retainers traveling between villages by wa'a kaulua (double hulled canoe), a carving of Lono and kahili (feather standards) accompany them. Puowaina (Punchbowl) is shown in the background. Also depicted is he'e nalu (surfing) on olo (long surfboard) and 'o'o ihe (sport of spear throwing) whereby a group of men, at a given signal, hurl their spears at one man who would either catch the spears, dodge them, or otherwise fend them off.</description><location>Lester McCoy Pavilion</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/19300102.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1930.01.02</objectid><discipline>Mural</discipline><title>The Makahiki Festival - The Mauka Mural</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.290959</latitude><longitude>-157.851265</longitude><artloc latitude="21.290959" longitude="-157.851265" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="5" _uuid="28356B36-436C-4831-98AA-1CB236C85C5D" _position="5" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/5"><creator>Charles Dickey</creator><date>1935</date><description>Three sets of double doors and three top panels of an aluminium alloy in the Art Deco style. Located at the Honolulu Fire Department Central Station.</description><location>Honolulu Fire Department Central Station</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/193501.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1935.01</objectid><discipline>Door</discipline><title>Central Fire Department Doors</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.311151</latitude><longitude>-157.859057</longitude><artloc latitude="21.311151" longitude="-157.859057" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="6" _uuid="8C18816E-0C6F-4116-9B38-7B5B4ADD78DE" _position="6" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/6"><creator>Kate Kelly</creator><credit>Gift of the Amelia Earhart Memorial Committee</credit><date>1935</date><description>A cast bronze commemorative plaque set into a monolith. The plaque memorializes Amelia Earhart's first flight to Hawaii in 1935. Located at the Diamond Head Lookout.</description><location>Diamond Head Lookout/Kuilei Beach Cliffs</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/193701.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1937.01</objectid><discipline>Plaque</discipline><title>Amelia Earhart Memorial Plaque</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.256139</latitude><longitude>-157.804769</longitude><artloc latitude="21.256139" longitude="-157.804769" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="7" _uuid="E755C31C-A4ED-407F-A4CC-FC701DE0F3B9" _position="7" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/7"><creator>Marguerite Louis Blasingame</creator><credit>Funded by the Works Progress Administration</credit><date>1939</date><description>The stone bas relief entry way to the 1939 Board of Water Supply building. The bas relief is executed on a series of green steatite stone blocks which depict mythical and human Hawaiian figures, flora, and animals in the upper portions flanking either side of a central doorway as well as stylized letter forming a narrative text beneath the figurative panels. The two panels, one on the Diamond Head side of the entry way and the other on the other side of the entry door both depict stories involving the god Kane and Kaneloa in a mythical story about the discovery and use of water. Located at the Board of Water Supply Engineering Building Entrance.</description><location>Board of Water Supply Engineering Building Entrance</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/193901-5.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1939.01</objectid><discipline>Mural</discipline><title>Ka Wai Ake Akua</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.306108</latitude><longitude>-157.852555</longitude><artloc latitude="21.306108" longitude="-157.852555" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="8" _uuid="5E1D2074-D2DA-4099-B924-15958CB9F29D" _position="8" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/8"><creator>Juliette May Fraser</creator><date>1958</date><description>A mural depicting various agricultural activities occurring in Hawaii over several time periods, from pre-contact to the 20th century. Located in the Board of Water Supply Building Lobby.</description><location>Board of Water Supply Building Lobby</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/195801.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1958.01</objectid><discipline>Mural</discipline><title>Pure Water - Man's Greatest Need</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.306008</latitude><longitude>-157.853896</longitude><artloc latitude="21.306008" longitude="-157.853896" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="9" _uuid="27F748DE-733C-4F40-B55C-DC3517CC9047" _position="9" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/9"><creator>Charles Watson</creator><date>1959</date><description>A stylized sculpture of a giraffe with the body made of welded rebar rings. The body is articulated by using weld material to give the spotty look of the animal. The head is approximately 12" long and it peers down its mouth open, and with long eyelashes. There are ears and horns on its head and there are iron rods of about 4-6" in length that are used to articulate the hairs on the back of the giraffe's neck. The base on which the giraffe sits is made of concrete with stones set into it. The piece was installed at the Honolulu Zoo in 1992. Located at the Honolulu Zoo Elephant Exhibit.</description><location>Honolulu Zoo Elephant Exhibit</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/002/198912.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1989.12</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Giraffe</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.270449</latitude><longitude>-157.819816</longitude><artloc latitude="21.270449" longitude="-157.819816" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="10" _uuid="20040B4A-44DB-44C7-AE79-0851768C9750" _position="10" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/10"><creator>Yoshinari Kochi</creator><date>1960</date><description>A roughly carved "C" form which represents "century," supported by a pillar with four Chinese characters on the sides which signify that "blessings from heaven are invoked by peace and harmony." The sculpture commemorates the 75th anniversary of the first Japanese immigrants to arrive in Hawaii. Located at Foster Botanical Garden.</description><location>Foster Botanical Garden</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/196001.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1960.01</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Hiroshima Monument</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.316633</latitude><longitude>-157.858247</longitude><artloc latitude="21.316633" longitude="-157.858247" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="11" _uuid="2224A27F-5906-4B38-87B1-0EA0553E2181" _position="11" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/11"><creator>Giordano</creator><date>1967</date><description>A hollow cast bronze bust of Neal Shaw Blaisdell, Mayor, City and County of Honolulu, 1955-1969. The bust depicts Mayor Blaisdell with a wide collared shirt and sits atop a square planter which is part of the bronze casting. The casting then rests on a rectangular exposed aggregate cast concrete pedestal base. The bronze exterior has a dark brown sulphide-type patina which has been evenly applied over the exterior. The surface of the bronze is heavily modulated with surface textures depicting hair, skin and shirt features. Located in the foyer of the Neal Blaisdell Concert Hall.</description><location>Neal Blaisdell Center Concert Hall Foyer</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/196701.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1967.01</objectid><discipline>Bust</discipline><title>Neal Shaw Blaisdell</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.301282</latitude><longitude>-157.84976</longitude><artloc latitude="21.301282" longitude="-157.84976" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="12" _uuid="3D92BEE2-72BC-4B4D-AE59-3E133169145F" _position="12" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/12"><creator>Michael Weidenbach</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><date>1995</date><description>Stone sculpture of Indiana limestone of a Hawaiian woman carrying a gourd. The orientation of the sculpture has the figure looking towards Tahiti in recognition of early migrations to Hawaii. Located on the grounds of the Mission Memorial Auditorium.</description><location>Mission Memorial Auditorium Grounds</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/003/199904-7.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1999.04</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Nana I Ke Kumu (Look to the Source)</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.304938</latitude><longitude>-157.856514</longitude><artloc latitude="21.304938" longitude="-157.856514" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="13" _uuid="127B3DB0-EA19-4C72-8E81-1C27E53A3E6A" _position="13" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/13"><creator>Jodi Endicott</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><date>2000</date><description>A Life-size sculpture of a seated male reading the newspaper with three mice on his shoulder entitled "What's Next (Hawaii's Journey; Wearing Our Past and Looking to the Future)." Located at Bishop and King Streets.</description><location>Bishop Street at King Street</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/003/200002-3.JPG</imagefile><objectid>2000.02</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>What's Next</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.308382</latitude><longitude>-157.861889</longitude><artloc latitude="21.308382" longitude="-157.861889" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="14" _uuid="900C1FB3-7D06-49A9-A62B-F11410328350" _position="14" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/14"><creator>Ernest DeCoito</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><date>1987</date><description>The sculpture represents one of the purposes of the Fire Training Center-to accomplish a given goal through team work and individual sacrifice. The sculpture is an assembled piece consisting of combined individual parts working together to depict a recognizable form. Kulamanu is translated as a place where birds gather, a coming together, or gathering place. The choice of a bird form was a creative decision by the artist. It was not intended to signify a specific bird or make a statement. Located in the Charles Thurston Fire Training Center courtyard.</description><location>Charles Thurston Fire Training Center Courtyard</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/198506.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1985.06</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Kulamanu</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.339891</latitude><longitude>-157.930945</longitude><artloc latitude="21.339891" longitude="-157.930945" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="15" _uuid="BD532B8C-4441-435C-92EC-417ACB799897" _position="15" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/15"><credit>Gift of Hawaiian Memorial Park</credit><date>1981</date><description>Bronze bas-relief plaque of a fireman carying a girl accompanied by a policeman. Located at the Charles Thurston Fire Training Center Courtyard.</description><location>Charles Thurston Fire Training Center Courtyard</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/198101.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1981.01</objectid><discipline>Plaque</discipline><title>Fire and Police Memorial Plaque</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.339869</latitude><longitude>-157.930806</longitude><artloc latitude="21.339869" longitude="-157.930806" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="16" _uuid="54C11DC3-6963-4D1F-ADBC-9086240DAB35" _position="16" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/16"><credit>Gift from the City of Kaoshiung, China</credit><date>1989</date><description>A pair of stone Chinese guardian lion figures. Located at Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Park.</description><location>Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Park</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/002/198911.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1989.11</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Lucky Lions</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.310656</latitude><longitude>-157.861776</longitude><artloc latitude="21.310656" longitude="-157.861776" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="17" _uuid="F142B78E-57E7-4E06-9CBD-5DA1EADD0109" _position="17" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/17"><creator>Paul Saviskas</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><description>Life size stainless steel figure of a sea turtle (honu). Located at Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Park.</description><location>Dr. Sun Yat-sen Memorial Park Pond</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/003/199902-2.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1999.02</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Turning on a Dime aka "Honu" (Sea Turtle)</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.310708</latitude><longitude>-157.861607</longitude><artloc latitude="21.310708" longitude="-157.861607" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="18" _uuid="80B073BB-AB45-45D3-9E04-E175C4E85146" _position="18" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/18"><creator>Jill Burkee</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><date>1994</date><description>Twelve bronze medallions each representing an animal of Chinese astrology mounted on an exterior parapet wall. The animals are modeled in medium to high relief with a background in the manner of a dish with a radiating textured finish. Located at Chinatown Gateway Plaza.</description><location>Chinatown Gateway Plaza Roof</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/002/199436.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1994.36</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Chinese Zodiac Medallions</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.310903</latitude><longitude>-157.862061</longitude><artloc latitude="21.310903" longitude="-157.862061" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="19" _uuid="8CCD421C-BAA1-4687-8AD7-C305B77CF042" _position="19" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/19"><creator>Isamu Noguchi</creator><credit>City and County of Honolulu Purchase</credit><date>1977</date><description>An abstract nonrepresentational steel sculpture composed of three equidistant straight steel pipe legs connected at the top by a horizontal undulating tubular form. The steel of the sculpture is painted black overall. At groundlevel at the center, the space is defined by a stepped two-part circular concrete platform. Located at the Honolulu Civic Center.</description><location>Frank F. Fasi Civic Center Lawn</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/197718-2.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1977.18</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Skygate</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.304579</latitude><longitude>-157.855664</longitude><artloc latitude="21.304579" longitude="-157.855664" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="20" _uuid="2A7B3CAA-2EAA-4FB0-9EB5-88E886741B60" _position="20" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/20"><creator>Jodi Endicott</creator><credit>Gift of Jodi Endicott</credit><date>1996</date><description>Three concrete figures depicted on inner tubes, two male and one female, installed on a concrete base. Located on the Honolulu Civic Center grounds.</description><location>Frank F. Fasi Civic Center Lawn on Alapai Street</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/003/199803.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1998.03</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Tubers</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.304816</latitude><longitude>-157.853169</longitude><artloc latitude="21.304816" longitude="-157.853169" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="21" _uuid="86535D25-BD5F-479E-9624-E381E6BE05F2" _position="21" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/21"><credit>Gift from the City of Nagasaki, Japan</credit><date>1990</date><description>A bronze bell topped with a crane supported by four steel posts with a stone clad base. The bell is a replica of the bell from the tower of Urakami Cathedral in Nagasaki, Japan. Located on the Grounds of the Honolulu Civic Center near Beretania Street.</description><location>Frank F. Fasi Civic Center Lawn on Beretania Street</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/002/199027.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1990.27</objectid><discipline>Bell</discipline><title>The Bell of Nagasaki</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.305601</latitude><longitude>-157.854923</longitude><artloc latitude="21.305601" longitude="-157.854923" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="22" _uuid="69F1D69B-B9BE-47BA-AF20-A163DA37A0BA" _position="22" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/22"><creator>George M. Williams</creator><credit>Gift of Nichiren Shoshu of America</credit><date>1985</date><description>Bronze replica of the Liberty Bell. Located in front of the Mission Memorial Building on South King Street.</description><location>Mission Memorial Building Front Lawn</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/198508.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1985.08</objectid><discipline>Bell</discipline><title>Aloha Liberty Bell Replica</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.304434</latitude><longitude>-157.856495</longitude><artloc latitude="21.304434" longitude="-157.856495" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="23" _uuid="519F3DE0-6121-466F-9E9C-3A0F5DB2736B" _position="23" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/23"><creator>Carl Ruiz</creator><credit>Gift of the Filipina Society of Hawaii with the Oahu Filipino Community Council</credit><date>1983</date><description>Life-size standing figure of Dr. Jose Protacio Rizal, national hero of the Philipines against Spanish colonial rule who was executed at age 35 in 1896. The figure sits on a high pedestal in the style of monumental bronzes. There is a plaque in the center of the pedestal at the front, and two other plaques on the sides. Located on College Walk at North Beretania Street.</description><location>College Walk at North Beretania Street</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/198301-4.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1983.01</objectid><discipline>Sculpture</discipline><title>Jose Rizal</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.314604</latitude><longitude>-157.862161</longitude><artloc latitude="21.314604" longitude="-157.862161" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="24" _uuid="6958C4E5-B7E4-4AF1-8D17-C069D3CCEE2C" _position="24" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/24"><creator>Masahiko Katori</creator><credit>Gift of the City of Hiroshima, Japan</credit><date>1984</date><description>Replica of the bell at Hiroshima, Japan's Peace Memorial Park. Located on College Walk near North Kukui Street.</description><location>College Walk at North Kukui Street</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/198507.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1985.07</objectid><discipline>Bell</discipline><title>Hiroshima Peace Bell</title><access>Full</access><latitude>21.31545</latitude><longitude>-157.86086</longitude><artloc latitude="21.31545" longitude="-157.86086" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="25" _uuid="5FD55B24-8EC9-4DC4-9DC2-70B341458791" _position="25" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/25"><creator>Edward Stasack</creator><credit>Gift of the Downtown Improvement Association</credit><date>1967</date><description>Five ten foot wide concrete panels depicting Hawaiian petroglyphs. Less than two of the panels are visible, the other panels are hidden behind the Satellite City Hall. Located at the Fort Street Mall Satellite City Hall.</description><location>Fort Street Mall Satellite City Hall</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/002_196901-3.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1969.01</objectid><discipline>Mural</discipline><title>Petroglyphs</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.309206</latitude><longitude>-157.862157</longitude><artloc latitude="21.309206" longitude="-157.862157" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="26" _uuid="C2146CE2-5A22-4275-B374-6C8A7BB952BC" _position="26" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/26"><credit>Gift of the Governor of Fukuoka, Kyushu, Japan</credit><description>Stone hexagonal lantern in the Japanese Yukimi style. Located at the Foster Botanical Garden Daibutsu Terrace.</description><location>Foster Botanical Garden Daibutsu Terrace</location><imagefile>http://hiculturearts.pastperfect-online.com/34250images/001/197301.JPG</imagefile><objectid>1973.01</objectid><discipline>Lantern</discipline><title>Fukuoka Yame</title><access>Limited</access><latitude>21.316233</latitude><longitude>-157.857715</longitude><artloc latitude="21.316233" longitude="-157.857715" needs_recoding="false"/></row><row _id="27" _uuid="DE397EC3-995F-431B-9CE6-FCA8D5670E7D" _position="27" _address="http://data.honolulu.gov/resource/yef5-h88r/27"><date>1963</date><description>Cast stone moon lantern. The bottom image is that of the brown bear holding a money piece or "tinah." The tinah represents the promise of great and mutually profitable trade between the states of Hawaii and Alaska. The totem pole is carved out of red cedar. The accompanying plaque reads, "'This is my Hawaii... here I was brought up and educated; and it was here that I came to know what modern, civilized governments are like and what they mean.' Dr. Sun Yat-sen. In 1879, at the age of thirteen, Sun Yat-sen came to Hawaii from Zhongshan, China. It was here in Honolulu, that he spent many of his teenage years growing up and being educated. China's first revolutionary society the Xing Zhong Hui (Revive China Society) was organized in Hawaii in 1894. Sun Yat-sen went to overthrow the Qing Dynasty and establish a democratic China in 1911. The dedication of this statue recognizes t he sacrifice and support of the people of Hawaii in nurturing the roots of 'Modern China' and it's Founding Father. The Dr. Sun Yat-sen Hawaii Foundation, November 12, 2007."
